Description: Wheel-made pottery oinochoe (wine-jug) with a short concave messily finished foot, a bulbous, slightly sagging body, a single handle, a neck and a pinched spout; covered with a thick cream-yellow slip overlain with rough black and red painted patterns: A rough thin line in black paint swirled around the base of the handle and neck (splits into two in parts). Below, garlands painted in red and then surrounded by thin black lines. A black cross is painted above almost all garland curves. This pattern repeats in a larger size below. At the bottom of the lower garlands are more black crosses below the joins of each garland. Where it tapers to the base, two more rough black lines painted. Handle and top of rim covered in red paint.
Bibliographic references: Adams 1986 / Ceramic Industries of Medieval Nubia, Part I, Part II (Figure 58) (Type M7)
